messages.text:
Hi all, been struggling with this issue

I currently have a dataframe consisting of 3 assets and a timestamp

I've been trying to get the compound growth of each of the assets but it's coming back incorrect (asset increases in value and compound growth returns less than 1x)

is anyone able to see where i'm going wrong?

attaching the main code:
```prices = assets[:, x]
println(string(x)*": start - "*string(assets[:1, x])*", end - "*string(last(assets, 1)[:1, x]))
dates = assets[:, 1]

df[:, x] = diff(log.(assets[:, x]))

cumulativeprod = (cumprod(df[:, x] .+ 1))

compound_growth = prod(df[:, x] .+ 1)
println(string(x)*": compound growth - " * string(compound_growth))

n_periods = size(assets, 1)
annual_return = (compound_growth^(periods_per_year/n_periods)-1)*100
ar[:, x] = [annual_return]```
and what the println's are returning:
```brka: start - 120450.0, end - 197800.0
brka: compound growth - 1.5245186742783305
brkb: start - 80.11, end - 132.04
brkb: compound growth - 1.5150777648833422
gme: start - 22.88, end - 28.04
gme: compound growth - 0.847837471902966
1×3 DataFrame
 Row │ brka     brkb     gme      
     │ Float64  Float64  Float64  
─────┼────────────────────────────
   1 │  8.8067   8.6715  -3.24996```

messages.text:
is anyone able to break down for me what this does `diff(log.(assets[:, x]))` i thought it was effectively the percentage difference of 2 rows of a vector, which is kind of is, but it's not very accurate

two consecutive assets of price: `200081` and `197800` , the above gives the difference of `-0.0114659`
but calculating the difference you get the answer `-0.01140038284` which isn't a massive difference, but obviously over thousands of assets, it adds up

why is the `diff(log.(assets[:, x]))` giving what i'm assuming is the wrong answer seeing that my results are out

to calculate the above^
`(((100/200081)*197800)/100)-1`

messages.text: Hello, I hope someone can help me to fix an error I'm getting while trying to start Jupyter Notebook. It's not the first time I'm using Jupyter on that system but it is the fırst time I got an error like that. It says that it is unable to precompile IJulia package, while Julia REPL (outside Jupyter) is precompiling it properly whenever I want it to. In case of Jupyter, it gives me a LoadError. Also it says that it has a problem with ZMQ package too, while Julia REPL doesn't output a thing when I run Pkg.build("ZMQ") - it's just giving a blank line and then it is ready for the next command. Can someone help?

elements.text: Hello, I hope someone can help me to fix an error I'm getting while trying to start Jupyter Notebook. It's not the first time I'm using Jupyter on that system but it is the fırst time I got an error like that. It says that it is unable to precompile IJulia package, while Julia REPL (outside Jupyter) is precompiling it properly whenever I want it to. In case of Jupyter, it gives me a LoadError. Also it says that it has a problem with ZMQ package too, while Julia REPL doesn't output a thing when I run Pkg.build("ZMQ") - it's just giving a blank line and then it is ready for the next command. Can someone help?

messages.text:
Is this a bug?  I have a package Foo in my JULIA_LOAD_PATH.  If I do:
```julia> using Foo
[ Info: Precompiling Foo [top-level]
ERROR: LoadError: ArgumentError: Package HTTP not found in current path:
- Run `import Pkg; Pkg.add("HTTP")` to install the HTTP package.```
So then I try
```(v1.5) pkg> activate Foo
(Foo) pkg> add HTTP
> using Foo
using Foo
[ Info: Precompiling Foo [984f741b-9a08-4955-ba0e-338b96f43b49]
┌ Warning: Package Foo does not have HTTP in its dependencies:
...```
What appears to be going on is that it only looks in cwd()/Foo for the Project.toml instead of in JULIA_LOAD_PATH/Foo.  Do I have to cd to Foo/.. every time to be able to manage the package depedencies properly?

elements.text: Is this a bug?  I have a package Foo in my JULIA_LOAD_PATH.  If I do:

julia> using Foo
[ Info: Precompiling Foo [top-level]
ERROR: LoadError: ArgumentError: Package HTTP not found in current path:
- Run `import Pkg; Pkg.add("HTTP")` to install the HTTP package.
So then I try

(v1.5) pkg> activate Foo
(Foo) pkg> add HTTP
> using Foo
using Foo
[ Info: Precompiling Foo [984f741b-9a08-4955-ba0e-338b96f43b49]
┌ Warning: Package Foo does not have HTTP in its dependencies:
...

What appears to be going on is that it only looks in cwd()/Foo for the Project.toml instead of in JULIA_LOAD_PATH/Foo.  Do I have to cd to Foo/.. every time to be able to manage the package depedencies properly?

Thanks!

messages.text:
Hi, Julia deals with *Nothing* *type* in such way that an object initialized with *nothing* does/returns nothing, in other words, the *Assignment operator =* can deal with *Nothing type*. That feature and the Nothing type evaluation isnothing() are useful to develop algorithm. In order to fully take advantage of Nothing type could you consider *extended Nothing type to other operators*? For examples:
1/ a = 1 + nothing should return 1
2/ a=nothing
    a[:,:] or view() should do nothing
Am I the one how need that feature?
Best.

2/ a=nothing
    a[:,:] or view() should do nothing
Am I the one how need that feature?
Best.

messages.text: HI, I'm having issues with the julia workflow I have cloned a repo checked out my own branch, done some changes, committed them, but no matter what I do in the julia repl, update, rm and re add, precompile, restarting julia, activating the branch workspace and trying from there, using dev instead of add. It never seems to pick up my new changes. even when i change the sub version in the toml file, and it picks up the version change, it still doesnt pick up the actual code change. Any advice would be much appreciate :)

It never seems to pick up my new changes. even when i change the sub version in the toml file, and it picks up the version change, it still doesnt pick up the actual code change. You recently used a password to access the repository at PumasAI/Pumas.jl with git using git/2.0 (libgit2 0.28.2).

Basic authentication using a password to Git is deprecated and will soon no longer work. Visit <https://github.blog/2020-12-15-token-authentication-requirements-for-git-operations/> for more information around suggested workarounds and removal dates.

messages.text: Once I create ensemble systems, How could we save the solution in text or csv files ? Thats my code > <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/how-to-save-ensemble-solutions/54876>

attachments.title: How to save ensemble solutions?
attachments.text: Once I create ensemble systems, How could we save the solution in text or csv files ? γ = 0.2647 D = 0.4811 μ= 34 u₀=34 #7.0 f(u,p,t) = -γ*(u - μ) g(u,p,t) = sqrt(D) dt = 1 tspan = (1,60) prob = SDEProblem(f,g,u₀,tspan) sol = solve(prob,EM(),dt=dt,save_noise=true) ensembleprob = EnsembleProblem(prob) sol = solve(ensembleprob,EnsembleThreads(),trajectories=100) plotly() plot(sol,linealpha=0.4,xlabel = “Time (years)”,ylabel = “Carbon Price (USD/tCO2)”)
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: How to save ensemble solutions?

elements.text: Once I create ensemble systems, How could we save the solution in text or csv files ? Thats my code >

messages.text:
I am probably missing something very obvious. Can someone help me understand this?
```foo_string = "foo"
foo_dict = Dict("f"=>0, "o"=>0)```
this:
```haskey(foo_dict, "f")```
returns: `true`

but why does
```for char in foo_string
    print(char, " ", haskey(foo_dict, char))
end```
returns this?
```f false
o false
o false```
What is a Julian way to check if a character in a string is in a dictionary key?

Thanks in advance.

    print(char, " ", haskey(foo_dict, char))

In the original code, line 122 is the bad line, but when running the code in the MWE, I’m not sure it’s going to be as bad. At first I thought it was simply that I should give a bit more typ...

messages.text:
This pattern seems wierd to me:
```    retval = false 
    for i = 3:5 
        retval = calc_true_false_value()
        if retval 
            return retval
        end       
    end    
    return retval```
I need that `if` statement there because if `retval = true`  for `i  = 4` (but false for `i = 5`), it overwrites the value for the final return statement. In other words, I want the function to return as soon as `retval = true` for either `i = 3, 4, 5`. I think there is a better way to do this, maybe a while loop?

elements.text: This pattern seems wierd to me:

retval = false 
    for i = 3:5 
        retval = calc_true_false_value()
        if retval 
            return retval
        end       
    end    
    return retval
I need that
if
statement there because if
retval = true
for
(but false for
), it overwrites the value for the final return statement. In other words, I want the function to return as soon as
retval = true
for either
. I think there is a better way to do this, maybe a while loop?

messages.text:
Hey folks. So I have seens these expressions all over the place in julia code, in particular in the flux tutorials and also in some diffeq code, but I am not sure why they are used or what the full explicit syntax would otherwise be. So in the Flux tutorial there is an expression like
``` gradient(()->y(x), params([W, b]))```
Where there is this `() -> `, syntax. The julia docs call these zero-argument anonymous funtions, and I understand what anonymous functions are. But I was not clear why there is an empty tuple, etc. This is one of those things that I have never payed attention to in passing, but I figured I should now actually try and understand why and when to use zero argument anonymous functions with this syntax.

elements.text: Hey folks. So I have seens these expressions all over the place in julia code, in particular in the flux tutorials and also in some diffeq code, but I am not sure why they are used or what the full explicit syntax would otherwise be. So in the Flux tutorial there is an expression like
gradient(()->y(x), params([W, b]))

Where there is this `() -> `, syntax. The julia docs call these zero-argument anonymous funtions, and I understand what anonymous functions are. But I was not clear why there is an empty tuple, etc. This is one of those things that I have never payed attention to in passing, but I figured I should now actually try and understand why and when to use zero argument anonymous functions with this syntax.

messages.text:
Is it easy to call Go from Julia? What about Rust? What are the biggest challenges? What about the other direction, i.e. them calling Julia?
I’m looking for two things. One is that I could do microservices in a modern language that gives me small binaries that execute fast. The other would be to use libraries in one language in the other, so the amount of libraries would be a factor.

elements.text: Is it easy to call Go from Julia? What about Rust? What are the biggest challenges? What about the other direction, i.e. them calling Julia?

I’m looking for two things. One is that I could do microservices in a modern language that gives me small binaries that execute fast. The other would be to use libraries in one language in the other, so the amount of libraries would be a factor.

messages.text:
Which do you guys find more aesthetic? in-line `if` blocks or ternary operators?

```julia> c = true
true

julia> x = if c "a" else "b" end
"a"

julia> x = c ? "a" : "b"
"a"```

messages.text:
Question about JLD2: I was surprised by this behavior:
```using JLD2

@save "test.jld2" v = [2,4,6]

global jldfile = jldopen("test.jld2", "r")

function f(perm)
    v = jldfile["v"]
    return permute!(v, perm)
end

f([1,2,3]) # [2,4,6]  <-- expected
f([3,2,1]) # [6,4,2]  <-- expected
f([1,2,3]) # [6,4,2]  <-- surprise: actually changed `jldfile["v"]`.```
It seems that if I open a .jld file (`jldfile` above), I'm not so much holding a reference to data in the jld-file that I can then "request" from, I'm really holding the actual data, so if I request a bit of the data in `jldfile`, I literally get that data - not a copy of it - and if I then modify it, any subsequent request for the same data-field in `jldfile` would give me back a modified version.
Can someone explain why this is working this way? I was kind of caught off guard by this (I guess because I had thought it would be a copy on every new "request").

elements.text: Question about JLD2: I was surprised by this behavior:
It seems that if I open a .jld file (
jldfile
above), I'm not so much holding a reference to data in the jld-file that I can then "request" from, I'm really holding the actual data, so if I request a bit of the data in
jldfile
, I literally get that data - not a copy of it - and if I then modify it, any subsequent request for the same data-field in
jldfile

would give me back a modified version.
Can someone explain why this is working this way? I was kind of caught off guard by this (I guess because I had thought it would be a copy on every new "request").

```(v1.5) pkg> add OrdinaryDiffEq
   Updating registry at `~/.julia/registries/General`
┌ Warning: Some registries failed to update:
│     — `~/.julia/registries/General` — registry dirty
└ @ Pkg.Types /buildworker/worker/package_linux64/build/usr/share/julia/stdlib/v1.5/Pkg/src/Types.jl:1194

Updating `/gpfs/home/tharvey2/.julia/environments/v1.5/Project.toml`
  [1dea7af3] + OrdinaryDiffEq v5.43.0
Updating `/gpfs/home/tharvey2/.julia/environments/v1.5/Manifest.toml`

  [4fba245c] + ArrayInterface v2.13.7
.
.
.

[ Info: Precompiling OrdinaryDiffEq [1dea7af3-3e70-54e6-95c3-0bf5283fa5ed]
ERROR: LoadError: ArgumentError: Package Adapt [79e6a3ab-5dfb-504d-930d-738a2a938a0e] is required but does not seem to be installed:

Stacktrace:

.
.
.```
It appears that only v5.43.0 of OrdinaryDiffEq is being downloaded every time...I am not sure if this is the issue, but I can't seem to get any more recent version to download...
Also instantiate did nothing

messages.text:
I have a general question about Julia's multithreading; specifically about defaults. Should it be easier to limit the number of threads used by a Julia program in common cases?
Background: We're developing a code that's intended to be run on a cluster, with many jobs running simultaneously on each node. To make the best use of the resources, it's important that every Julia job uses only a single thread, and that there is one job per CPU core on each node. To achieve this, we tried using the `julia -t1` option, but that's not enough. In our code, it was also necessary to do
```using LinearAlgebra
using FFTW
BLAS.set_num_threads(1)
FFTW.set_num_threads(1)```
It took us a while to figure out that these libraries will default to using multiple threads. I'm wondering if it would make a sense if there were a convention for libraries to "automatically" pick up the `-t1`  option to Julia? The motivation is, obviously, to avoid simultaneous Julia processes from slowing each other down.

elements.text:
I have a general question about Julia's multithreading; specifically about defaults. Should it be easier to limit the number of threads used by a Julia program in common cases?
Background: We're developing a code that's intended to be run on a cluster, with many jobs running simultaneously on each node. To make the best use of the resources, it's important that every Julia job uses only a single thread, and that there is one job per CPU core on each node. To achieve this, we tried using the
julia -t1
option, but that's not enough. In our code, it was also necessary to do

using LinearAlgebra
using FFTW
BLAS.set_num_threads(1)
FFTW.set_num_threads(1)

It took us a while to figure out that these libraries will default to using multiple threads. I'm wondering if it would make a sense if there were a convention for libraries to "automatically" pick up the
option to Julia? The motivation is, obviously, to avoid simultaneous Julia processes from slowing each other down.

messages.text:
I'm preparing a mini-course for Julia and hoping to use some memes. I wonder if I'm missing a conditional in between these states of the mind-body meme:
```if(condition) f() end

ifelse(condition,f(),nothing)

condition ? f() : nothing

condition && f()```
Thanks!
